children.desc: Hollow stems. Berries useful for cuisine.
children.name: Sambucus nigra

children.desc:
Fruit leather

http://arcadianabe.blogspot.com/2013/07/red-elderberry-experiment-1.html
children.name: Sambucus racemosa

children.desc:
Tolerant of moisture. Wood foul smelling (when cut?). Flowers sweetly fragrant. Small tree to 30 ft. Fruit sweet and edible and attractive to birds. Long lived to 150 years.

Low root damage potential.

https://selectree.calpoly.edu/tree-detail/viburnum-lentago
children.name: Viburnum lentago

children.desc:
Candidate for bioremediation of saline soils. Eat the tissue to remove salt from the environment. Salt is concentrated in glands in the leaves.

Leaves can be eaten raw.
Seeds can be made into flour.

http://www.ethnoherbalist.com/southern-california-native-plants-medicinal/four-wing-saltbush/
children.name: Atriplex canescens

children.desc:
Flowers, fruit, and leaves are edible. Could be used as an interesting method of bioremediation to remove salt from the soil.


https://www.laspilitas.com/nature-of-california/plants/105--atriplex-lentiformis-breweri
children.name: Atriplex lentiformis

children.desc:
Racemes of white flowers smell of green apples.

Culture and Germination: "https://www.fs.fed.us/database/feis/plants/shrub/mallau/all.html"
children.name: Malosma laurina

children.desc: Fast growing sun loving tree to 49 ft.
children.name: Rollinia deliciosa

children.desc: Non-native host for Papilio zelicaon.
children.name: Foeniculum vulgare

children.desc: Host plant for various butterflies. Perennial Ascelpias that should be cut down in late fall to prevent transfer of pathogens between generations of butterflies.
children.name: Asclepias curassavica

children.desc: Probably annual bloomer. Extremely fragrant, one of the most fragrant hoyas.
children.name: Hoya australis tenuipes

children.desc:
Smells like jasmine.

"The flowers are extremely fragrant, but have a short lifespan of around 4 days.  I have found that this Hoya likes to be grown warm and humid or can easily be susceptible to root rot.  I lost all of the buds from multiple peduncles when I over watered in a cool greenhouse. I got it to re-bud and open flowers quickly by re-potting with a two inch layer of hydroton on the bottom of the pot, and placing the plant into a very warm and humid grow-tent."

https://vermonthoyas.com/hoya-species/hoya-bhutanica/
children.name: Hoya bhutanica

children.desc:
"A fast grower and an early bloomer. The bloom color is so unique and different than any other Hoya! The glossy corolla is tomato red color and the corona is off white to light pink. In my opinion, the flowers smell like lemon zest. My mother plant bloomed in less than 6 months from a small plant and then it become a frequent bloomer (literally all the time for me). The leaves on this Hoya are thick, glabrous, shiny with visible veins. This Hoya is sort of new in the market. I think most collectors see it as a must have. I would even recommend it to a beginner."

gardinonursery
children.name: Hoya ilagiorum

children.desc:
"The first time I saw Hoya incrassata at Selby Gardens in Sarasota, FL I fell in love with it. The foliage is so elegant and more beautiful than Hoya crassicaulis. I got a cutting from the Selby curator and it grew really fast and started to bloom less than a year later. Hoya incrassata has very pretty yellow flowers with red tips and white corona. This Hoya blooms non-stop through out the warm months when mature and the flowers have a really nice citrus fragrance. My mother plant is always loaded with several clusters at a time."

http://gardinonursery.com/hoyas/1422-hoya-incrassata.html
children.name: Hoya incrassata

children.desc:
"EPC-777 - I am loving this hoya that grows little bow ties for leaves - growing from a rooted cutting was without issues - the greenery starts out a bit pubescent - the trumpet-shaped goldenrod-colored flowers are tiny but beautiful and full of dark red sap that does not ever drip - peduncles develop at many nodes along the upright vines - this one has larger leaves than the other Hoya manipurensis species I grow - this is a fast grower with little or no care aside from the normal light and moisture - the sap is very sweet when it touches my tongue"

srqhoyas.com
children.name: Hoya manipurensis

children.desc:
"The species has appealing glossy green leaves with a pretty vein pattern. The leaves will turn beautiful shades of reds and purples if you expose it to high light (not full sun). The venation intensifies with these stunning colors. I would recommend for the foliage lovers.
Once established, it produces fragrant yellow flowers. This species is a reliable bloomer for me during the warm months."

gardino nursery
children.name: Hoya merrillii

children.desc:
"This Hoya is native to Hat Som Paen in Thailand. It has very attractive, medium size, dark green foliage that sometimes develop some silver flecks.
The flowers are so lovely! The corolla is all white and the corona is big and really pops. It is dark pink color with light pink edges. There is yellow color under the corona which really goes nicely with all the colors. Sometimes the yellow is more prominent and it makes the flowers even more stunning. The flowers also have a delicious spicy scent. This hoya blooms frequently for me once established."

gardinonursery
children.name: Hoya sp. Hat Som Paen IML 1438

children.desc:
"I received Hoya stoneana as a small rooted cutting from Joni at SRQ Hoyas in June of 2012.  The plant came with the name Hoya siamica and I grew it as such until I found out in summer of 2014 that it was in fact Hoya stoneana.  It grew well from the start and produced numerous peduncles all to no effect.  The peduncles would also form annular rings like it had flowered many times before, but alas I could never spot the formation of any buds.  I do believe that the plant did form buds but they were too small to see with the naked eye, and they would abort immediately and thus created the peduncle rings.  Finally in the spring of 2014 I put the plant directly outdoors where it would get dappled sunshine and be exposed to temperatures as low as the mid 40°s.  It did not take long after that cool weather exposure to set buds and keep them.  It flowered in July and many times during that summer.

The flowers are very strongly fragrant and will perfume an entire house.  I would not say that they are the most pleasing to the nose; smelling somewhat floral with a strong dash of chlorine thrown in for good measure. "

https://vermonthoyas.com/hoyas-n-z/hoya-siamica/
children.name: Hoya stoneana

children.desc:
"Hoya surigaoensis IML1693. Look at the rachis. It has bloomed for me year around. Great Hoya!"

https://twitter.com/hoyaplants/status/663730472745308160

Possible nocturnal fragrance of coconut.
children.name: Hoya surigaoensis

children.desc: Nocturnally fragrant flowers.
children.name: Macrosiphonia brachysiphon

children.desc: Medium sized elephant ear with oblong-lanceolate leaves.
children.name: Alocasia Boa

children.desc: Small to medium sized elephant ear, cute.
children.name: Alocasia gageana

children.desc: To 4 ft. Attractive saggitate-lanceolate leaves.
children.name: Alocasia lauterbachiana

children.desc: White or purple bract with pink spadix. Flowers scented.
children.name: Anthurium amnicola

children.desc: Bee pollinated.
children.name: Anthurium formosum

children.desc: Green leaves tinged with purple. Hirsute.
children.name: Philodendron hastatum

children.desc: Often called incorrectly "Philodendron cannifolium". Found as an epiphyte and rarely a terrestrial, this plant has attractive bulb-like petioles and grows in a rosette.
children.name: Philodendron martianum

children.desc: Short for a palm. Fruit can be eaten raw, made into wine, or processed into jelly. Fruit does not keep long, even when refrigerated.
children.name: Butia capitata

children.desc: Fruit traditionally eaten by native americans. May be resistant to red palm weevil, but there are known infestations.
children.name: Washingtonia filifera

children.desc: Edible buds and flowers. Stir fried or raw.
children.name: Hemerocallis

children.desc: Flowers have a honey scent.
children.name: Acourtia wrightii

children.desc: Its stems grow from a substantial colony of rhizomes which require a minimum soil depth of 16 cm and can grow in fine to coarse soils. The stems grow erect and range in height from 0.5–2.5 metres (1.6–8.2 ft). Although A. douglasiana can reproduce from seed, it's primarily propagated from division and spreading of its underground rhizomes. The extensive rhizomes help prevent erosion by stabilizing streambanks.
children.name: Artemisia douglasiana

children.desc: Late blooomer for an Aster. Medium bush to 2 ft x 2+ ft.
children.name: Aster ageratoides 'Ezo Murasaki'

children.desc: Drought tolerant bush with asteroid flowers. Attracts beneficial insects and birds.
children.name: Baccharis pilularis consanguinea

children.desc: Bright orange-yellow flowers appear May-June. Native to Californian deserts. Hairy stem. Taproot. Goes dormant after flowering. May not flower in first year.
children.name: Balsamorhiza sagittata

children.desc: Wafting scent of chocolate. Low growing dandelion-like rosette with long-stemmed flowers. Maybe good candidate for polyculture.
children.name: Berlandiera lyrata

children.desc:
Bidens are edible and keep well. As a potherb, they have good texture when cooked. It is not recommended to eat the raw leaves as they may have a high saponin level.

http://www.eattheweeds.com/spanish-needles-pitchfork-weed/
children.name: Bidens

children.desc: Good candidate for lawn.
children.name: Boltonia asteroides

children.desc: Yellow flowers.
children.name: Chaenactis glabriuscula

children.desc: Hardy weed plant. Good for naturalization. Some may experience irritation on contact.
children.name: Conyza canadensis

children.desc: Host plant for a native butterfly. Nectar plant for many other insects.
children.name: Corethrogyne filaginifolia

children.desc: Large thistle tribe member. Stalks can be used like palm heart.
children.name: Cynara cardunculus

children.desc: Blooms all year.
children.name: Dahlia tenuicaulis

children.desc: Dahlia stems are hollow and can be used for various things.
children.name: Dahlia

children.desc: Native perennial sunflower growing in chaparral and woodland communities throughout much of California. Forms clumps of dark green, lance shaped leaves under a foot tall.  Blooms April through June with small, golden-yellow sunflower heads which rise above foliage 18 inches to 2 ft. tall.  Plant in full sun to light shade where it will be quite drought tolerant once established. The flowers attract a wide array of pollinators and beneficial insects.
children.name: Helianthella californica

children.desc: Double form.
children.name: Helianthus decapetalus 'Plenus'

children.desc: Inhabits sand dunes. Short lived perennial.
children.name: Helianthus niveus

children.desc: Short cultivar.
children.name: Helianthus tuberosus 'Dwarf Sunray'

children.desc: The stems are hollow, fragile and often floppy. Plants bloom in late winter to early summer, with normally one or two flower heads per stem, on 15 to 30 centimeters long peduncles, but sometimes 4 or more flowers can be found per stem.
children.name: Leptosyne maritima

children.desc: Some members have deep roots to 12 ft. Useful for stabilization.
children.name: Liatris

children.desc: Edible as salad green and tea. Valuable ruderal.
children.name: Matricaria discoidea

children.desc: Long bloom period from March to November. Attractive native. Light honey fragrance.
children.name: Melampodium leucanthemum

children.desc: Dwarf cultivar.
children.name: Solidago Little Lemon

children.desc:
Cascade Creek goldenrod is a superior form of this native discovered by master plantsman Roger Raiche.  The flower heads 
are large and compact and do not flop like other types. Perfectfor habitat gardeners in low and very low water conditions it will attract a variety of creatures like native butterflies and other pollinators to the garden in summer and fall.
children.name: Solidago velutina californica 'Cascade Creek'

children.desc: Enjoys hot weather. Drought tolerant. Good candidate as annual biomass producer.
children.name: Tithonia rotundifolia

children.desc: Ornamental purplish-pink flower. Edible tubers. Wind dispersed seeds.
children.name: Tragopogon porrifolius

children.desc: Native from southern Arizona to west Texas, this semi-woody perennial has gray-green needlelike leaves. In the summer it is covered with many small, papery white flowers with orange centers.The persistent flower petals turn tan and papery. Plant in full sun and well-drained soils.
children.name: Zinnia acerosa

children.desc: Edible-ish young fronds.
children.name: Athyrium filix-femina

children.desc: Dense prickly impassible foliage. Good hedge to grow unpruned. Great wildlife value.
children.name: Mahonia nevinii

children.desc: Fast growing with willow-like leaves. Has dormancy period. Hummingbirds like to nest in this tree in the summer.
children.name: Chilopsis linearis

children.desc: A very beautiful deciduous tree to 25 feet tall with smooth dark green palmately compund leaves and furrowed light gray bark. The 2-3 inch long lavender-pink flowers with yellow centers appear in clusters in early spring, covering the bare branches. Unlike its yellow relative, Tabebuia chrysotricha this tree takes several years to flower, but its worth the wait! Tabebuia species are generally known for their tolerance to coastal conditions but this plant prefers a warm sunny site away from the beach. Plant in a warm spot for best floral display. Listed as hardy to 24° but survived 18° without damage in the freeze of December 1990 in the nursery garden. Tabebuia impetiginosa was introduced into cultivation in Southern California in 1964 by the Los Angeles State and County Arboretum in Arcadia where the largest specimen in California puts on its floral display annually.
children.name: Tabebuia impetiginosa

children.desc:
Attractive fragrant yellow flowers. Warm bloomer.

https://selectree.calpoly.edu/tree-detail/tecoma-stans
children.name: Tecoma stans

children.desc: Highly ornamental. Blooms in dry season.
children.name: Tecomanthe dendrophila

children.desc: Flowers honey scented! Leaves can be blanched. Mature leaves can be boiled or fried.
children.name: Crambe maritima

children.desc: Nocturnal fragrance.
children.name: Matthiola longipetala

children.desc: Strongly fragrant flowers produced late spring and early fall. Bark has strong camphor smell when scraped. Flowers are pollinated by beetles of the family Nitidulidae.
children.name: Calycanthus occidentalis

children.desc: Berries edible but bitter. Sun to shade.
children.name: Lonicera interrupta

children.desc:
Creeping Snowberry grows on north slopes, in ravines, and sometimes is all that's left of an oak woodland in full sun. The more coastal the setting the more sun this snowberry can handle. In some of the shady ravines the light intensity is so low you have to use 400 speed film at noon to take a picture. I've seen Creeping Snowberry along the edge of an interior climate in the heavy shade of Umbellularia californica and Quercus agrifolia a few miles from here where they were growing flat and 5' across with the leaves 1 foot between nodes.
Creeping snowberry was planted at CALM (California Living Museum) in Bakersfield in full sun; looks excellent there for a month each year, when it is in flower and the new leaves are coming out. Then the leaves burn off on the first hot day. But in San Luis Obispo it is over by the Mens Colony in full sun and it looks fine.
children.name: Symphoricarpos mollis

children.desc: Blooms all year. Valuable hardy nectar plant.
children.name: Peritoma arborea

children.desc: Seasonal color.
children.name: Cornus californica

children.desc: Not seemingly invasive, but overutilized in gardens. Beautiful berries but maybe consider this less.
children.name: Cornus kousa

children.desc:
Fresh gourd can be eaten like squash, though the mature fruit is extremely bitter.
Seeds can be roasted or boiled and eaten.
Oil can be extracted from whole seeds. 
Seeds contain 31% crude protein.
Taproot extremely starchy, with 47.5-56% starch content dried.
children.name: Cucurbita foetidissima

children.desc: Stress deciduous.
children.name: Cucurbita palmata

children.desc: Ornamental red fruits white white stripes.
children.name: Diplocyclos palmatus

children.desc: Frost tolerant to 15 F.
children.name: Acacia covenyi

children.desc: Fragrant yellow flowers. Short lived at <50 years. Experiences fire in natural habitat and resprouts from roots. Seeds germinate after fire.
children.name: Acacia pycnantha

children.desc:
Pendulous branches resembling a the form of a weeping willow. Pods split open when ripe. Thornless. Salt tolerant.

"This tree, native to eastern Australia, has been widely planted in urban areas of the Sonoran Desert. Seeds are germinating away from parent plants which might allow this to become an exotic invasive."

http://www.arizonensis.org/sonoran/fieldguide/plantae/acacia_salicina.html

Root Damage Potential Rated as Low.

https://selectree.calpoly.edu/tree-detail/adenostoma-sparsifolium
children.name: Acacia salicina

children.desc:
http://www.friendsofthewildflowergarden.org/pages/plants/fragrantfalseindigo.html

Fragrant False Indigo grows from a stout deep taproot. The plant does not spread vegetatively but instead by seed dispersal. It adapts to most soils, does best in full sun with mesic to dry conditions, but sandy soils are best avoided.
children.name: Amorpha nana

children.desc: Produces taproot with lateral rhizomes.
children.name: Baptisia australis

children.desc:
Blooms nearly all year. Atractive roundish bush to 6 ft. Thornless The leaves close up at night or if the plant is heavily disturbed/broken. 

http://www.arizonensis.org/sonoran/fieldguide/plantae/calliandra_californica.html

Stress deciduous. Cold and drought stressed.

http://www.wildscaping.com/plants/plantprofiles/Calliandra_californica.htm
children.name: Calliandra californica

children.desc: Pink flowers, winter deciduous.
children.name: Cercis occidentalis

children.desc:
Cute flowers and foliage. Seeds jump up when broken apart and cling to you.

http://www.friendsofthewildflowergarden.org/pages/plants/pointedleafticktrefoil.html
children.name: Desmodium glutinosum

children.desc:
Seeds buoyant and stay viable for up to 5 years at sea.

Peas, young pods, tendrils edible.

https://wildfoodgirl.com/2011/wild-beach-pea-stir-fry-with-dandy-flowers/

Stabilizes sand dunes. Grows alongside halophytic grasses (e.g. Leymus mollis).

http://arcadianabe.blogspot.com/2014/09/beach-pea-elusive-edible.html
children.name: Lathyrus japonicus

children.desc: Spreading weeping low canopy. Deciduous. Lives 50 to 150 years.
children.name: Prosopis glandulosa var. torreyana

children.desc:
Fragrant pink racemes of faboid flowers.

https://www.fs.fed.us/database/feis/plants/tree/robneo/all.html
children.name: Robinia neomexicana

children.desc: Purple flowers that smell like grape soda.
children.name: Sophora secundiflora

children.desc: Flowers fragrant. Lifespan less than 50 years. To 20 feet in height x 20 feet in width.
children.name: Vachellia constricta

children.desc: Sweetly fragrant flowers.
children.name: Vicia faba

children.desc:
Grown as a cover crop. Binds sand. Cold sensitive. Can produce flower and fruit all year.

Grown as food crop in some places. Maybe safest to eat young pods.
children.name: Vigna marina

children.desc: 60 days from seed to fruit. Once first fruits are produced, it will keep producing until frost.
children.name: Vigna unguiculata sesquipedalis

children.desc: Slow growing at about 1 ft per year.
children.name: Quercus douglasii

children.desc:
Utility-friendly. Root damage rated as low. 

https://selectree.calpoly.edu/tree-detail/quercus-durata
children.name: Quercus durata

children.desc:
Height to 70 ft, width to 80 ft. Grows moderately at 1 to 2 ft per year. High shading capcity. Root damage potential rated as moderate. 

https://selectree.calpoly.edu/tree-detail/quercus-wislizeni
children.name: Quercus wislezeni

children.desc: Drought tolerant.
children.name: Carya illinoensis

children.desc: http://www.californiagardens.com/Plant_Pages/juglans_californica.htm
children.name: Juglans californica

children.desc:
To 60 feet in height and width. Long lived to 50 to 150 years. Allelopathic.

Nuts can be made into high-protein flour.

Rated by Pollen Library as SEVERE allergen.

http://www.pollenlibrary.com/Local/Specie/Juglans+hindsii/in/Santa%20clara%20County/CA/
children.name: Juglans hindsii

children.desc:
Provides blooms all winter.

Hypoestes aristata is a fast-growing shrub that grows up to 1.5 m high. It produces soft, hairy, dark green oval leaves and has attractive lilac  pink or white  flowers borne in spike-like inflorescences. It flowers from May right through winter till early spring.

It is usually found in dry thicket, forest and damp places from the Eastern Cape in the south to tropical Africa in the north.

Ribbon bush is eaten as spinach in some areas, while traditionally crushed leaves are used as a poultice for sore eyes. It also makes a good cut flower because it lasts well in water.

The ribbon bush can be propagated from both seeds and cuttings. When seeds are sown in August they will germinate in three weeks. It also tends to seed itself in the garden. You can collect a handful of seeds and sow them in containers or plastic bags until they are large enough to be planted directly in the garden. Ribbon bush should be watered well in summer but less in winter and it needs to be pruned back after flowering. It requires very little attention because it grows easily in the garden.
children.name: Hypoestes aristata

children.desc:
It has blue-lavender flowers with a foliage scent similar to a tangy lavender. The odor is rich and luxurious. Flowers are scented lightly of honey. Desert lavender is great for hot narrow spaces that need some height. Such as narrow planting area against a hot south facing stucco wall or that narrow area between two hot concrete driveways that you need a hedge in places like Palm Springs. Desert Lavender is major bee plant in the Desert. It likes perfect drainage and a little water after established. It like full sun and can take extreme desert heat and wind. Desert Lavender will freeze to ground on cold winters. It seems to be hardy to about 25 F.. The plant has that slate blue-gray look that seems to be so popular. A wonderful plant to try in a hot sunny flower bed that does not get a lot of water. Remember that it grows in desert washes, not up on the dry hillsides, so a little water. It is not a cactus but grows where you would find a desert willow. 

Leaves can be used for tea. Tolerates flooding.
children.name: Hyptis emoryi

children.desc:
http://mother-natures-backyard.blogspot.com/2016/04/plant-of-month-april-fragrant.html

Leaves have minty but unique fragrance. Can be used to flavor tea. L. fragrans does not take well to being pruned in late fall.
children.name: Lepechinia fragrans

children.desc: Fragrant leaves. Drought tolerant once established. Larval host for some lepidopterans. Unappealing to deer or rabbits.
children.name: Phlomis fruticosa

children.desc: Fast growing to 6'x4' ft. Fall blooming, should be cut in winter to maintain bushiness.
children.name: Plectranthus ecklonii

children.desc: Everblooming.
children.name: Salvia flocculosa

children.desc: Giant-flowered variety.
children.name: Salvia patens 'Cabrillo Giant'

children.desc:
The most well known of the tuberous mints is Stachys affinis, the Chinese artichoke. The tubers of Chinese artichoke are generally small, two to three inches (5 to 7.5 cm) in length, and no more than half an inch (1.2 cm) wide. They are white, with a segmented appearance that makes them tempting to compare to grubs. They are crisp and slightly nutty tasting and are often eaten raw, but also can be cooked or pickled. All parts of the plant are edible, but only the tubers are really worthwhile, in my opinion. Yields are fairly small; a quarter pound (114 g) from an individual plant is very good.  Chinese artichoke plants reach about 18 inches (45 cm) in height.  Chinese artichoke is diploid.

In most places, Chinese artichoke is one of those plants that you really have to grow yourself. It is rarely available in markets and it doesn’t store very well. In climates where the soil doesn’t freeze to significant depth, it is best harvested and used fresh through fall and winter. A fresh Chinese artichoke tuber has the texture of a radish, with a flavor that combines elements of radish, turnip, and walnut (in my opinion of course), while tubers that have been sitting in a box at the store for more than a day or two may have no flavor at all.

Can be pickeled.
children.name: Stachys affinis

children.desc: In its native sites it grows roadside drainage ditches and standing in water. In containers it grows too fast and becomes a pot bound mess in nothing flat. This is one of the few natives that do not care how pot bound, old, frost burnt even drought stressed it is , as soon as it gets in a wet spot look out! It will sucker until there is no more moisture.
children.name: Stachys chamissonis

children.desc:
Florida betony is quite similar to Chinese artichoke, but the tubers are usually quite a bit larger.  The flavor is less nutty, more bland.  I think this species has great potential compared to Chinese artichoke, because it generally has better yields and readily produces seed, which means that it can be more easily improved through breeding.

The tubers of Florida betony may reach up to twelve inches (30 cm) in length and about three quarters of an inch (2 cm) in diameter.  Florida betony plants reach up to about 24 inches (60 cm) in our climate.
children.name: Stachys floridana

children.desc:
Roots, leaves, seeds edible. 

Tubers - raw or cooked[K]. A wholesome and nutritious food[4], they have a pleasant mild nutty flavour[K]. The tubers can be dried and ground into a powder that is used in making bread etc[2, 4, 12, 115, 183]. The tubers are formed in the autumn[17]. Although quite small, they are fairly smooth and produced in a reasonable quantity so are not too fiddly to utilize[K]. Young shoots - cooked. Used as an asparagus substitute[183]. A pleasant taste but the smell is disagreeable[4]. Seed[257]. No further details are given[257].

https://www.pfaf.org/user/Plant.aspx?LatinName=Stachys+palustris

Marsh woundwort tubers may grow as long as eighteen inches (46 cm) although most of that lenth is rather thin.  It is still perfectly edible and may even be preferable for some dishes.  I find that the thicker, more useful part of the tubers is typically about four to six inches (10 to 15 cm) in length.  Marsh woundwort plants reach up to about 40 inches tall (102 cm) in our climate.  Marsh woundwort is found in diploid, tetraploid, and hexaploid forms. The diploids and tetraploids are mostly native to North America, while the hexaploids are mostly native to Europe (Luczaj 2011).
children.name: Stachys palustris

children.desc: Can be made into tea. Flowers in spring, fall and winter. Extremely drought tolerant once established.
children.name: Trichostema lanatum

children.desc: Highly attractive bush with flowers occuring any time during the year in warm climates. Highly attractive to hummingbirds.
children.name: Cuphea micropetala

children.desc:
Fire resistance is Favorable, Root damage potential is rated as Low.

https://selectree.calpoly.edu/tree-detail/punica-granatum
children.name: Punica granatum

children.desc: Edibility rating of fruit is the lowest of the Baobabs. Edible but unpalatable.
children.name: Adansonia madagascarensis

children.desc: Leaves edible and sour or tart. Used as vegetable raw or cooked. Leaves mucilaginous.
children.name: Hibiscus acetosella

children.desc: Pioneer plant that can grow on rocky substrate. Gives way to successive plants easily, not known to have an invasive growth pattern. Pretty fernlike leaves.
children.name: Comptonia peregrina

children.desc: Edible flower and fruit.
children.name: Acca sellowiana

children.desc:
Midgen Berry. Midyim.
Sweet tasting berries.
children.name: Austromyrtus dulcis

children.desc: Strongly fragrant white flowers.
children.name: Mirabilis longiflora

children.desc:
Desert Olive is a deciduous shrub that grows fast to 6-8 feet. Native from northern central California to Riverside and east to Colorado and Texas. Useful fast filler for desert conditions, drought tolerant after established, cold tolerant to at least 0 F., and deer have not bothered this plant. Easy to grow. Give it regular water for first year, then forget or keep watering. LOVES deep sand.

It's kind of weird that our Olive grows in the same situations as the European olive, but the European Olive grows in areas of twice as much rainfall and milder locations. Our Olive is much tougher.

Plants occurring nearby are Prunus andersonii, Encelia actoni, Haplopappus linearifolius, Chaenactis spp., Atriplex canescens, and Cucurbita foetidissima, in arroyo area of Joshua Tree Woodland.
children.name: Forestiera pubescens

children.desc: Very showy white flower clusters. Medium tree at 20 - 25 ft. in height.
children.name: Fraxinus dipetala

children.desc:
Utility-friendly. Fragrant flowers. Root damage rated as low.

Rooted floating plant whose sometimes branching stems reach 4 meters long.

Native but INVASIVE

California IPC rates it highly.
Fruits contain many minute seeds. Vegetative reproduction through fragmentation also possible. Tends to shade other aquatic plants.

children.desc: Preferred host is Manzanita (Arctostaphylos sp.).
children.name: Pedicularis densiflora

children.desc: Blooms mainly in spring but sporadically year-round.

children.desc: State flower. Blooms when warm.

children.desc: Sympatric with Quercus wislizeni.
children.name: Pinus sabiniana

children.desc: Drought and winter deciduous. Signifcant hummingbird plant.

children.desc: Clumping grass. Ornamnetal seed heads.

children.desc: Roots reach down to 4 ft. Good for stabilization and soil remidiation.
children.name: Bromus carinatus

children.desc:
Very useful for soil remidiation and erosion prevention. Dense roots grow straight down to 13 ft. Very sturdy against flood.

Must get sterile variety, or else it's invasive. Still self-propagates through plantlets, but not stolons.

Sterile varieties:
Monto Vetiver
Sunshine Vetiver
Louisiana Sunshine

https://www.houzz.com/discussions/1925112/sterile-vetiver
children.name: Chrysopogon zizanioides

children.desc: Tall canes act as windbreak. Attacked by boring insects. Uses a lot of water. Leaves valuable carbon soure for mulch.
children.name: Saccharum officinarum

children.desc: Possible candidate to plant under walnut etc.
children.name: Anemone hepatica

children.desc: Resistant to oak allelopathy, maybe resistant to others.
children.name: Aquilegia eximia

children.desc: Resistant to oak allelopathy, maybe resistant to others.
children.name: Aquilegia formosa

children.desc: White flowers. Flowers and leaves fragrant.
children.name: Carpenteria californica

children.desc: Stress deciduous.
children.name: Thalictrum fendleri

children.desc: Grows in nutrient-poor soils and rocky outcrops. Sometimes co-dominant with toyon (Heteromeles arbutifolia). In nature, periodic fires burn it to the crown, after which it resprouts. The roots keep the soil from washing away. To facilitate this, the leaves produce flammable oils.
children.name: Adenostema fasciculatum

children.desc:
Leaves and flowers fragrant. Low canopy. 

Fire resistance rated as "unfavorable". 

https://selectree.calpoly.edu/tree-detail/adenostoma-sparsifolium
children.name: Adenostema sparsifolium

children.desc: Young leaves have fuzz. Small to medium tree to 39 ft tall. Slightly fragrant delicate white flowers. Excellent tree for bird habitation.
children.name: Amelanchier arborea

children.desc: Fragrant-leafed. Sun to shade.
children.name: Chamaebatia foliosa

children.desc: Fast growing.
children.name: Eriobotrya japonica

children.desc:
They are visited by butterflies, and have a mild, hawthorn-like scent. The fruit are consumed by birds, including mockingbirds, American robins, cedar waxwings and hermit thrushes.[14] Mammals including coyotes and bears also eat and disperse the pomes.

Fruit contain cyanogenic glycosides.
children.name: Heteromeles arbutifolia

children.desc: Quick growing upright tree.
children.name: Lyonothamnus floribundus

children.desc: Native to Central Asia, Mandchurian Apricot is a small, rounded tree reaching 15 to 20 feet in height. The leaves are broad, simple, ovate or broad-elliptic and mostly smooth, medium green turning golden yellow in the fall. The fragrant showy flowers are single, pink and over 1 inch wide, blooming in the spring before the leaves emerge. It is very attractive in Flower, very cold hardy and can be relied on in climates where other Prunus may not flower. Fruits are about 1 inch in diameter, yellow with red flush, showy, edible and borne in abundance. The fruit provides food for wildlife during the fall. Fruits can be eaten fresh and are excellent for making jams and jellies.
children.name: Prunus mandschurica

children.desc: Tolerates some drought, but thrives in moisture. Forms impenetrable thicket with hooked thorns like velcro.
children.name: Rosa californica

children.desc:
Root damage rated as low.

https://selectree.calpoly.edu/tree-detail/sorbus-alnifolia

Invasive potential: little invasive potential

http://edis.ifas.ufl.edu/st598
children.name: Sorbus alnifolia

children.desc: Fragrant flowers that occur in summer. Nectar plant for butterflies, but not known to be a larval host.
children.name: Cephalanthus occidentalis

children.desc: Popular butterfly plant that blooms almost constantly in warm conditions and produces profuce nectar. Brightly colored and very ornamental.
children.name: Ixora coccinea

children.desc: Small fruit with pulp that tastes like blackberry jam. Slow and compact grower with dense branching habit. Gardenia-like scent on flowers appearing in the fall and winter. Suitable for container culture. Produces food 1 to 1.5 years from seed.
children.name: Randia formosa

children.desc: Performs well in a climate with a distinct dry period. Fruit is said to taste like banana and have the texture of custard.
children.name: Casimiroa edulis

children.desc: Long lived tree. You've had this before. Tastes amazing after refrigeration. Soft texture.
children.name: Manilkara zapota

children.desc: Wild sprawling bush. Needs regular pruning to look neat.
children.name: Buddleja alternifolia

children.desc: Man-made hybrid. Strong night fragrance. Amazing ornamental value.
children.name: Cestrum Orange Peel

children.desc: Contains nicotine. May act as a natural pest-repellent. High ornamental value.
children.name: Nicotiana sylvestris

children.desc: Extremely fragrant and free-flowering.
children.name: Solanum crispum 'Glasnevin'

children.desc: Some report no fragrance under the name S. jasminoides. Many report slight to good fragrance for S. laxum 'Album'.
children.name: Solanum laxum 'Album'

children.desc: A beautiful 2-3' perennial with dark green glossy foliage and deep blue-purple 1" flowers that are scented like violets but better. A sweet wonderful headturning smell. Native to the Gaviota pass area north of Santa Barbara. It is doing fine here at the nursery in the ground and fine at Cal Poly, SLO. A nice looking perennial that needs no water in most coastal gardens and can look formal as it flowers much of the year. It is native in clay, but does well here in sandy loam.
children.name: Solanum xanti hoffmannii

children.desc: Leaves and young buds edible. Yellow flowers cause diarrhea in high enough amounts.
children.name: Viola pedunculata

children.desc:
The crushed or rain-dampened leaves have a resinous creosote odor that some may find unpleasant.
The leaves give off a distinctive resinous odor after rains, especially in the summertime. Many people find this scent pleasant and evocative of rain in the Sonoran Desert.
These tough, clone-forming shrubs are extremely long-lived, potentially living for hundreds or even thousands of years.
children.name: Larrea tridentata
